label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
Yes, the post-Abbas era has begun. But the bad news is the legacy he leaves behind after twenty-one years in powerâ€”a legacy defined by three structural disasters.
First, a public debt exceeding $16 billion, entirely owed to domestic Palestinian sources: local banks, suppliers, pension funds, and unpaid salaries. This debt cannot be ignored or postponed. Even if 3 percent of Palestinian GDP were allocated annually to repayment, it would take decades to settleâ€”condemning generations to inherited insolvency.
Second, roughly 400 laws enacted by presidential decree in the absence of a functioning parliament. Reviewing, correcting, repealing, or replacing this distorted legislative framework will require years of intensive parliamentary workâ€”likely one to two full legislative terms devoted almost entirely to undoing past damage rather than legislating for the future.
Third, the sale of thousands of dunams of state land in the West Bank through so-called â€œallocation decisions,â€ representing one of the largest corruption schemes carried out beyond public scrutinyâ€”a structural crime whose consequences are extraordinarily difficult to reverse.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
PA reform: facts vs. slogans

Good news: we are entering a post-Abbas era.
Bad news: the institutional burdens left behind will take generations to fix.

Since the Palestinian parliament stopped functioning in 2007, Abbas shifted to rule-by-decree.
â‰ˆ450+ presidential decrees replaced legislation.
Revising, amending, or repealing this body of decrees will require 8â€“10 years of intensive parliamentary work.
That means three consecutive elected Palestinian Legislative Councils, assuming regular elections every four years, would be consumed largely by undoing this legacy.

At the same time, the PA accumulated ~$16B in debt and arrears.
Under current economic conditions, even a future democratic government would need 5â€“6 decades to repay this without debt restructuring and sustained external support.
In other words: four Palestinian generations would continue paying the price.

This is not about personalities.
It is about institutions, accountability, and the cost of governing without a functioning parliament.

There is only one real reform:
National legislative and presidential elections.
Anything else is cosmetic â€” slogans without substance.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
"Minds of Peace": Israelis and Palestinians negotiate in Loccum | https://t.co/ZHqHeusitz https://t.co/sBtytttO2u
Several men and a woman stand in the Protestant Academy in Loccum in front of a hand-drawn map of Israel, including the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. They are engaged in a lively discussion. The language constantly switches between English, Hebrew, and Arabic. No one here speaks German. The participants have come to Lower Saxony from Israel and the Palestinian Territories. The current topic of discussion is borders. It is just one of many issues that would need to be considered in a two-state solution. In three small groups, the participants are trying to develop proposals for such a solution.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
Rabbi Meir Bargeron in @JGfortwayne

"Israel today is a society living with collective trauma. That trauma touches civilians and soldiers, families and first responders, border communities and distant cities alike. Yet many of the people we met were resisting the idea that trauma must strip them of compassion or moral responsibility.

That resistance took another form when we met Samer Sinijlawi, a Palestinian peace activist committed to nonviolent resistance, trauma healing and grassroots relationship-building.
He spoke candidly about pain, anger and injustice â€” and just as candidly about the dangers of despair and dehumanization. He insisted that political agreements alone cannot sustain peace without human trust beneath them. His work centers on relationships: Israelis and Palestinians seeing one another as people rather than symbols.

For the first time in a long while, I felt something rare in conversations about this conflict: cautious hope."

https://t.co/45u9HblmYI

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
Gaza Deserves Life

This is not a position against anyone. It is a position for humanity. This child dancing at a wedding in Gaza reminds us of a simple truth too often lost in conflict:
children are not a threat, and they are not born as enemies.
Every child in Gaza and in Tel Aviv alike has the same right to safety, to joy, and to a future not governed by rockets or fear.

Real security is not built by force alone. It is built by creating a reality where children do not need hatred to feel protected.
Policies that suffocate the daily life of an entire society may create temporary calm, but they do not produce sustainable peace.

The dance in this video is not a denial of pain. It is an expression of resilience and attachment to life. And that is precisely what must be protected if we are serious about a different future.

Recognizing the right of Gazaâ€™s children to live does not undermine Israelâ€™s security. It strengthens the understanding that security and peace are not opposites, but partners.
A peace that ignores the humanity of the other will not endure.
A peace that begins with children may still be possible.
Gaza deserves life just as every  Israeli and Palestinian child in this land does.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
Why Israeli Skepticism Is Understandableâ€”And Why Engagement in the Board of Peace Is Essential

After several interviews with Israeli media following the launch of the @BoardOfPeace Board of Peace in Davos, I encountered deep skepticism.  Skepticism is not cynicism; it is experience.

But the initiative launched in Davos this yearâ€”the Board of Peace chaired by @realDonaldTrump President Donald J. Trumpâ€”is not another declarative peace process. It is a governing mechanism built around authority, leverage, and measurable outcomes. That difference matters.

In Davos, two visions of global order appeared side by side. One was familiar: speeches lamenting the collapse of the so-called rules-based international system. Leaders spoke openly of a â€œpleasant fictionâ€ coming to an end. For many in the Middle East, this was not a revelation. It was a delayed admission. The rules existedâ€”but they were applied selectively, enforced unevenly, and often detached from accountability.

The Board of Peace did not emerge to mourn this system or replace it rhetorically. It emerged from a different governing philosophyâ€”one skeptical of process for its own sake and focused instead on delivery. Clear authority. Defined responsibility. Measurable goals. Accountability.

When @jaredkushner Jared Kushner presented Gazaâ€™s future in Davos, he did not offer slogans or promises. He presented institutional design, budgets, timelines, and governance structures. For Palestinians and Israelis alike, this marked a departure from decades of diplomatic theater. It was not another promise to â€œsupport peace.â€ It was an attempt to build it.

For Palestinians, this matters because Gaza is not an abstraction. It is two million people living among ruins, where delay fuels extremism and institutional collapse empowers militias. Action is not ideological; it is moral.

For Israelis, the stakes are no less concrete. A reconstructed Gaza governed by accountable institutions is not a concessionâ€”it is a security interest. Stability achieved through functioning governance, economic dignity, and regional responsibility is more sustainable than deterrence achieved through force alone.

Israeli skepticism toward international mechanisms is justified. But disengagement would be a mistake. This process cannot succeed without Israeli involvement, scrutiny, and conditional support. Supporting the framework does not mean suspending doubtâ€”it means shaping outcomes.

Critics argue that action without universal consensus risks abuse of power. That concern is legitimate. But consensus without enforcement has already failed. The real question is not whether power will exist in peacebuilding, but whether it will be exercised transparently, responsibly, and with measurable accountability.

If this model succeeds, it will not be because it sounded better. It will be because it delivered schools instead of statements, salaries instead of sympathy, and security instead of slogans.

For Israel, this is not about faith in diplomacy. It is about advancing a strategic interest: replacing perpetual instability on its southern border with accountable governance. For the region, it is a test of whether reconstruction and cooperation can finally replace endless war management.

Skepticism is healthy. Engagement is essential. The difference between the two will shape what comes next.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text: Israelis and Palestinians are two peoples whose histories are tragically intertwined â€” and whose futures, whether they choose it or not, remain inseparable.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
The Board of Peace did not emerge from nostalgia for a fading system, nor from rhetorical protest against power politics. It emerged from a different governing philosophyâ€”one associated with @realDonaldTrump President Trumpâ€™s approach to statecraft: skeptical of process for its own sake, impatient with performative multilateralism, and focused on leverage, authority, and deliverables. What distinguishes this initiative is not ideology, but method: clear authority, defined responsibility, measurable goals, and accountability. Against a global backdrop saturated with moral language and procedural diplomacy, the Board represents an evolutionâ€”from statements to structure, from symbolism to responsibility. Rather than lamenting the end of a fiction, it attempts something riskier: building mechanisms that can be judged by outcomes.

When @jaredkushner Jared Kushner presented Gazaâ€™s future through concrete plans, data, and institutional design, it marked a clear departure from decades of diplomatic theater familiar to Palestinians and Israelis alike. This was not another promise to â€œsupport peace.â€ It was an architecture designed to produce it. Whether the Board of Peace ultimately reshapes the global order remains to be seen. But for Palestinians and Israelis, it already represents something more immediate and tangible: a shift from statement-based diplomacy to action-based governance. For too long, international institutions offered us language. Rarely delivery. In Gazaâ€”where devastation is total and trust is fragileâ€”action is not ideological. It is moral

He described the move to phase two as a shift â€œfrom emergency management to governance, from humanitarian containment to long-term regional stabilization.â€ He emphasized that â€œThis is a pivotal â€” and rare â€” moment, marking the beginning of a new governing phase for Gaza: one defined by competence, accountability, and reconstruction rather than factional rule.â€

text:
Thank you, Ambassador Seibert, for this important visit and for taking the time to meet with Kulna â€” Jerusalemites, Jews and Palestinians, working together with civic spirit to keep their city shared, livable, and humane, despite immense challenges.
Kulna represents the kind of genuine, grassroots bridge-building that still exists on the ground, far from conference halls and closed-door panels.
It is time for international donors â€” led especially by Germany â€” to rethink peace-funding strategies: shifting resources from the â€œghost peace industryâ€ of Chatham Houseâ€“style seminars and anonymous workshops to real, visible initiatives that engage the Israeli and Palestinian publics directly.
Peace needs reconciliation. Reconciliation needs courage â€” and visibility. Grassroots work like Kulnaâ€™s deserves both.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
Authority Transfer and Gazaâ€™s Disarmament: The Process Has Begun

Today, the National Committee for the Administration of Gaza approved the monthly public-sector salary budget for Gaza, totaling $100 million per month.

This budget is part of a professional and transparent salary system designed to raise living standards in Gaza and provide public-sector employees with a fair and dignified incomeâ€”one that supports stability, responsibility, and normal life.
This decision marks a first concrete step in the transfer of administrative authority to the National Committee for the Administration of Gaza. More importantly, it may prove to be the most effective step toward Gazaâ€™s disarmamentâ€”not through force, but through governance, dignity, and economic security.

When institutions function, salaries are paid, and people can live with dignity, extremism loses its oxygen.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
Hope is no longer a slogan. It is finally being built.

Today in #Davos26, I witnessed history.
The inauguration of the Board of Peace â€” a Board of Action â€” headed by @realDonaldTrump President Donald J. Trump, rightly described by @SecRubio Secretary of State Marco Rubio as a President of Action.
Most Palestinians and Israelis â€” if not all â€” recognize the leadership and determination President Trump and his team have shown in laying the foundations for a future of security, peace, stability, and prosperity that both peoples urgently need.
I had the honor to witness this moment live. The presence of the main regional players in the room was encouraging â€” and telling. I was not surprised by the absence of most European countries. Those present represent the future and the ability to adapt to change. Those absent remain anchored to the past, struggling to adjust to a rapidly emerging reality.
Whether the Board of Peace replaces the UN or not.
Whether it shapes a new world order or not.
For Palestinians and Israelis, it is something far more important: a Board of Action.
For decades, international institutions offered us statements. Rarely action.
This offers hope.
One of the most emotional moments for me was the video message from @AliShaathNCAG Dr. Ali Shaath â€” the voice of Palestinians, the voice of #Gaza, and above all, the voice of change. A living proof that action is no longer theoretical. It is underway.
And the most defining moment came when @jaredkushner Jared Kushner presented the future of Gaza through concrete plans and data. This was not the political theater we are used to.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
The discussion about Gazaâ€™s future would benefit from a more careful listening to Palestinian voices themselves.
Yes, Palestinians overwhelmingly support national unity. But they seek productive unityâ€”one that delivers accountable governance, dignity, and effective institutions, not the recycling of failed models.
Reattaching Gaza to the current Palestinian Authority leadership in Ramallah, without reform or renewal, risks deepening Gazaâ€™s suffering rather than alleviating it. A leadership that has accumulated approximately $16 billion in public debt, largely amid widespread allegations of corruption and mismanagement, is unlikely to inspire confidence in its ability to oversee the most complex reconstruction effort in Palestinian history with transparency and efficiency.
A governing system that struggles to manage the Allenby/King Hussein Bridge in a manner that respects citizens cannot credibly be expected to administer the far more sensitive Rafah Crossing. A health system that fails to provide adequate care in the West Bank cannot realistically rebuild Gazaâ€™s devastated medical sector. And a political elite increasingly disconnected from daily Palestinian realities cannot fully grasp what it means to live for months in displacement camps and temporary shelters.
Some Arab and European diplomats continue to insist on restoring the status quo in Gaza out of concern for â€œunity.â€ In many cases, this position reflects institutional inertia and political caution, rather than a deep understanding of Palestinian public sentiment or the scale of Gazaâ€™s post-war challenges.
Palestinians want unityâ€”but unity achieved through national elections, legitimate representation, and credible reform. Until such elections are possible, governance models must reflect present realities. Gaza today is not a peripheral issue; it has become the center of Palestinian political gravity. This shift may be uncomfortable for some policymakers, but ignoring it will only delay stability and reconstruction.
Listening to Palestiniansâ€”rather than deciding on their behalfâ€”remains the most responsible path forward.

The storm did pass, but at the cost of millions of lives. And history, as it always does, did not forgive.

Netanyahu, and many other â€œleaders,â€ flatter Trump, because they believe that in this world, only the bootlickers survive.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
That is why the creation of a senior Palestinian representative for reconciliation and regional cooperation is not optional. It is indispensable.

Such a role would not be symbolic. It would be structural â€“ serving as the connective tissue between international decision-makers and Palestinian society. It would ensure that reconstruction is not imposed, but owned; that lived experience informs policy, and that policy remains accountable to those it affects.

Its responsibilities would be substantive: leading postwar social stabilization and civic renewal; integrating demilitarization, deradicalization, democratization, and development into a coherent political framework; acting as a credible interlocutor with Israel capable of rebuilding trust across deeply eroded lines; and anchoring reconstruction in legitimacy so that international investment strengthens institutions rather than bypassing them.

If Phase II is to succeed, it must begin not with concrete, but with inclusion; not with management alone, but with legitimacy. Only then can reconstruction become more than buildings and balance sheets. Only then can it lay the foundation for dignity, accountability, and a shared future between two peoples whose histories are tragically intertwined â€“ and whose futures, whether they choose it or not, remain inseparable

This is not a conventional conference. It is a moral commitment to a people exhausted by war, and a clear message that Gaza is not destined for destruction, but is capable of life, hope, and a future.
At the heart of this moment are one million children in Gazaâ€”
children who, over the past two years, have endured suffering beyond human imagination.
They are not statistics in reports, but faces, dreams, and the natural right to a normal life.
This charter is a promise that reconstruction will be more than concrete and steelâ€”
that restoring life means restoring dignity before walls,
and building peace before buildings.
Peace for Gaza.
And for its children, a promise that tomorrow can be different.
With deep appreciation to @realDonaldTrump President Donald J. Trump, whose leadership made this process possible, and to his partners in the Board of Peace and the Executive Board specifically @jaredkushner @SEPeaceMissions for turning commitment into action.

text:
The start of meetings of Gazaâ€™s technocratic government in Cairo marks the opening of a new chapter in the lives of two million Palestinians, exhausted by an unprecedented war and years of devastation.
This may well be the most important government in Gazaâ€™s historyâ€”not only because of the immense challenges it faces, but because it is unlike anything the Palestinian political system has ever known. It is a government entrusted with managing the largest budget in Palestinian history, overseeing the most extensive reconstruction effort Gazaâ€”and arguably the modern Middle Eastâ€”has ever seen.
More than that, it is a government operating under conditions that have never existed before: broad international backing, unprecedented political attention, and a level of popular support rooted not in ideology or factional loyalty, but in sheer public exhaustion and a deep desire for normal life, dignity, and stability.
This government is not judged by slogans or rhetoric. It will be judged by its ability to restore basic services, rebuild homes and infrastructure, reopen schools and hospitals, revive the economy, and reintroduce the idea that governance can serve people rather than dominate them.
What begins in Cairo is more than a series of meetings. It is the first test of whether Gaza can move from survival to recovery, from despair to responsibility, and from endless crisis management to a future shaped by competence, accountability, and hope.

This is a pivotal â€” and rare â€” moment, marking the beginning of a new governing phase for Gaza: one defined by competence, accountability, and reconstruction rather than factional rule.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
Today marks a pivotal moment for Gaza.
The newly formed Technocratic Government of Gaza officially received its letters of appointment, signed by the Board of Peace, with a formal public announcement expected in the coming hours. This is not a symbolic step. It is the beginning of a new governing phase for Gazaâ€”one defined by competence, accountability, and reconstruction rather than factional rule.
What makes this moment historic is who this government representsâ€”and who it does not.
This cabinet is composed of independent Gazan professionals who belong neither to the Palestinian Authority nor to Hamas. These are individuals rooted in Gazaâ€™s society, economy, and institutionsâ€”many of whom lived through the war, endured its consequences, and remained engaged with their communities throughout the most difficult months.
Leadership and Key Figures
The government will be headed by Dr. Ali Shaath, a respected academic and public policy figure known for his technocratic approach, independence, and long-standing engagement with governance, development, and institutional reform.
Among the prominent members of the cabinet are:
@ayed621 Eng. Ayed Abu Ramadan â€“ a leading economic and private-sector figure in Gaza, widely recognized for his role in sustaining commercial life under blockade and conflict, and for advocating practical economic recovery mechanisms grounded in local capacity.
Dr. Samira Helles â€“ a seasoned professional with deep experience in public administration, social policy, and institutional rebuilding, bringing a strong focus on governance, transparency, and social resilience.
Hana Tarzi â€“ a prominent civil-society voice, representing community engagement, humanitarian coordination, and the lived experience of Gazaâ€™s social fabric during the war and its aftermath.
Together, these figures represent a new governing ethos: professional, civilian, locally anchored, and future-oriented.
What This Means for Gaza
This development is not merely a change of namesâ€”it is a structural shift.
Gaza is entering a phase that prioritizes:
Reconstruction over militarization
Institutions over factions
Service delivery over slogans
Economic revival over dependency
Dignity, accountability, and normal life over permanent emergency
The technocratic government is expected to focus on rebuilding critical infrastructure, restoring public services, stabilizing the economy, coordinating humanitarian and development efforts, and preparing Gaza for long-term governance reform and regional integration.
Beyond Gaza
This moment matters not only for Gazaâ€™s residents or for Palestinians as a whole.
A stable, functional Gaza governed by professionals rather than armed factions is a cornerstone for regional stability, Israeli-Palestinian de-escalation, and credible international engagement. It opens the door for reconstruction funding to be tied to transparency and performance, and for Gaza to re-enter regional economic frameworks rather than remain isolated and volatile.
This is not the end of Gazaâ€™s struggleâ€”but it may well be the beginning of its recovery.
For the first time in many years, Gaza is being offered something it has been denied for too long:
a chance to be governed by its people, for its people, with the future in mind.

text:
Despite decades of policies aimed at limiting Palestinian presence in East Jerusalem, Palestinians now make up around 40 percent of the cityâ€™s population. This is not an accident, and it is not temporary. It reflects a deeper demographic reality that cannot be wished or managed away.

If the two-state solution disappears, the alternative will be a one-state reality with a Palestinian majority between the river and the sea. That outcome would end Israelâ€™s ability to remain both Jewish and democratic.

The two-state solution is not a compromise for Israel. It is the best strategic outcome available. Separation is a demographic necessity. Delaying this decision only narrows the choices ahead.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
I want to commend @nmladenov Nickolay Mladenov for his recent visit to the region â€” a truly successful diplomatic start to Phase 2 of the Gaza peace and stabilization process.
As the U.S. and Regional.-backed Coordinator  for the Board of Peace / The Executive Board â€” Mladenov was welcomed by both Israelis and Palestinians, reflecting the trust he can built across the political spectrum. Something Gaza needs more than ever. His long experience as a diplomat and former UN Middle East envoy, with years spent engaging with Israeli, Palestinian, and regional stakeholders, makes him uniquely positioned to help bridge divides and advance confidence-building steps on the ground. 

During his meetings with senior officials in Jerusalem and Ramallah, Mladenov emphasized the importance of cooperation, practical progress, and broad engagement as the plan transitions from ceasefire to implementation. This constructive outreach sets a positive tone for what must be a phased and inclusive process â€” one that prioritizes stability, dignity, and a sustainable path forward for all civilians affected by years of conflict.

The region needs trusted leadership and committed diplomacy now more than ever. Mladenovâ€™s approach â€” grounded in experience, credibility, and balanced engagement â€” gives hope that the second phase can truly begin with momentum, cooperation, and a focus on concrete outcomes.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
If EU diplomats are to be discredited whenever hostile actors attempt to flatter them internally, then no serious engagement in conflict zones will remain possible. Diplomacy does not operate in moral laboratories. It operates in fractured realities, among actors who seek constantly to instrumentalize language, presence, and perception. To judge diplomats by how they are privately described by adversarial groups is to adopt the logic of propaganda, not policy.
The consequence of such a standard would not be stronger European principles, but weaker European influence. Access would diminish. Channels would close. The EU would increasingly outsource its presence to intermediaries or withdraw altogetherâ€”ceding ground not only to regional powers, but to precisely the radical actors it claims to oppose. The vacuum created by disengagement is never neutral; it is always filled by others.
What this article should therefore prompt is not a campaign of insinuation, retroactive moral scoring, or symbolic outrage, but a sober reaffirmation of how diplomacy actually worksâ€”and why it matters. Diplomats are not rewarded for being liked, nor disqualified for being quoted. Their mandate is to represent policy faithfully while navigating environments where clarity, restraint, and human engagement are essential toolsâ€”not liabilities.
In Gaza, this balance is uniquely difficult. Any envoy operating there must speak to suffering without legitimizing armed groups; must engage local realities without conferring political recognition; must defend universal principles while refusing ideological alignment. This is not moral ambiguity. It is professional discipline.
Sven KÃ¼hn von Burgsdorff operated within this narrow and demanding space. He defended EU principles, articulated internationally recognized rights, and preserved access in one of the most constrained diplomatic theaters in the world. This required maintaining a distinction that is central to European diplomacy: engagement without legitimization, empathy without endorsement, access without compromise.
Undermining that distinction does not strengthen Europeâ€™s moral standing. It erodes it. A Europe that confuses diplomacy with advocacy, or engagement with complicity, will find itself morally louder but strategically absentâ€”present in declarations, absent where influence is actually exercised.
In a region defined by polarization and absolutism, Europeâ€™s credibility has long rested on its capacity to hold complexity without surrendering principle. That capacity should be defended, not dismantled.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
Palestinians need a different kind of media coverageâ€”one that does not reduce Palestinian suffering to a fixed identity or frame it as a permanent condition with no political horizon.
When discussion on certain news channels turns into performance rather than serious, developmental analysis, it stops being journalism. It becomes theater. Emotion replaces inquiry, repetition substitutes for understanding, and the search for solutions is replaced by the management of outrage.
When suffering is presented not as a reality that must be confronted and changed, but as a defining and permanent traitâ€”an unavoidable fate with no political futureâ€”the risks are profound. And they are already unfolding. Palestinians risk being frozen inside a narrative that does not evolve: a closed story that allows no movement, no agency, and no space for internal debate.
In this kind of coverage, nuance and pluralism are often treated as betrayal. Internal criticism is framed as disloyalty. Any attempt to discuss responsibility, governance, or strategic decision-making is dismissed on moral grounds. The result is a discourse that generates international public sympathy while conditions on the ground continue to collapse, step by step.
Within this narrative, agency is outsourced to the outside world. The international community watches, reacts, and feelsâ€”but Palestinians are left trapped in an endless cycle of relived trauma. Media coverage relies heavily on continuous live reporting, yet rarely transitions into serious structural analysis. The recurring images of destruction and death produce emotional saturation rather than political clarityâ€”impact without direction.
It is precisely here that the de facto leaderships in Gaza and Ramallah find a comfortable environment. A discourse of permanent victimhood and continuous suffering serves them politically. This is not a denial of Palestinian sufferingâ€”no honest person could deny it. The suffering is real, deep, and unjust.
But the way the story is told matters.
This style of coverage deliberately obscures a central fact: de facto authorities govern Gaza and the West Bank, and they make strategic decisions. Some of those decisions are taken with prior awareness that they may provoke catastrophic consequences, paid for primarily by civilians.
Journalism that cannot hold empathy and truth at the same time does not help Palestinians move forward. It preserves pain without opening a path out of it.
What Palestinians needâ€”and what responsible media should offerâ€”is coverage that restores agency, acknowledges complexity, and insists that suffering is not an eternal destiny, but a reality that must be analyzed, confronted, and ultimately overcome.
